metadata.description: Track categorization for CreatiCode K-8 Grade 7-8 skills addressing age-appropriateness and competition preparation

track_definitions.standard: Core skills all students should master as part of regular K-8 CS curriculum
track_definitions.enrichment: Advanced but age-appropriate stretch goals for high-achieving students or optional deep dives
track_definitions.competition: Skills specifically targeting competitive programming (ACSL, Scratch Olympiad, etc.) or requiring AP-level knowledge

competition_track.title: Implement a sorting algorithm (bubble sort or selection sort)
competition_track.reason: Sorting algorithm implementation is AP Computer Science A content (typically grade 11-12). Requires understanding nested loops, swap logic, and algorithm correctness. Competition-appropriate for ACSL Junior Division.
competition_track.recommendation: Keep as competition track OR replace in standard curriculum with 'use library sort function as a tool'
competition_track.alternative_standard_skill: Use built-in sort blocks to organize data by criteria
competition_track.cognitive_level: Very High - Formal reasoning about algorithm correctness

competition_track.title: Understand recursion conceptually (algorithm calling itself)
competition_track.reason: Recursion is borderline but acceptable if kept purely conceptual and visual (fractals, nested patterns). Should NOT require students to write recursive functions in code.
competition_track.recommendation: Keep as enrichment with heavy visual scaffolding (Russian dolls, fractals, tree structures). Do NOT require implementing recursive functions.
competition_track.implementation_notes: Use visual examples only: fractals, nested dolls, family trees. Show the concept, don't require coding it.

competition_track.title: Analyze algorithm complexity and steps required
competition_track.reason: Formal complexity analysis (Big-O) is too advanced, but concrete step counting is appropriate with simplification.
competition_track.recommendation: SIMPLIFY: Focus on concrete counting ('this takes 10 steps, this takes 100'), NOT formal Big-O notation
competition_track.revised_approach: Count and compare steps in algorithms without formal complexity notation

competition_track.title: Compare deterministic and probabilistic algorithms
competition_track.reason: Understanding probabilistic algorithms is advanced but can be made accessible through simulations
competition_track.recommendation: Keep as enrichment with concrete examples: deterministic (always same result) vs. Monte Carlo (varies each run)

too_advanced_for_standard.title: Analyze two variables for potential causal relationships
too_advanced_for_standard.reason: Causal inference is college-level statistics. True understanding of causation vs correlation, confounding variables, and experimental design is beyond K-8.
too_advanced_for_standard.recommendation: SIMPLIFY DRASTICALLY: Change to 'Explore whether variables are related' without formal causal analysis. Use examples like 'Ice cream sales and drowning both go up in summer - why?'
too_advanced_for_standard.revised_title: Explore whether two variables are related
too_advanced_for_standard.revised_description: Students explore whether two variables seem to be related (when one is high, is the other high?) and discuss possible reasons, including that both might be affected by a third factor. No formal causal inference required.
too_advanced_for_standard.cognitive_level: Very High - Requires understanding confounding variables and experimental design

too_advanced_for_standard.title: Analyze unintended systemic impacts of a technology
too_advanced_for_standard.reason: Systemic analysis and second-order effects require systems thinking that develops later (typically high school). 12-13 year olds can list pros/cons but formal systemic/ripple effect analysis is too advanced.
too_advanced_for_standard.recommendation: SIMPLIFY: Change to 'List pros and cons of a technology' instead of systemic analysis. Students can identify good and bad effects without analyzing system-level ripple effects.
too_advanced_for_standard.revised_title: Identify pros and cons of a technology
too_advanced_for_standard.revised_description: Students identify and list 3-5 positive effects and 3-5 negative effects of a technology (e.g., smartphones, social media, AI assistants), discussing why each matters.
too_advanced_for_standard.cognitive_level: Very High - Second-order effects and systems thinking

too_advanced_for_standard.title: Analyze policy and regulation of an emerging technology
too_advanced_for_standard.reason: Formal policy analysis requires understanding government systems and regulatory frameworks beyond typical 8th grade civics.
too_advanced_for_standard.recommendation: SIMPLIFY: Change to 'Should there be rules about this technology?' - discussion-based, not formal policy analysis
too_advanced_for_standard.revised_title: Discuss whether rules are needed for an emerging technology
too_advanced_for_standard.revised_description: Students discuss whether there should be rules or laws about an emerging technology, who should make those rules, and what those rules might say. Focus on discussion, not formal policy analysis.
too_advanced_for_standard.cognitive_level: High - Requires understanding policy and governance

terminology_fixes_only.title: Implement a Monte Carlo simulation to estimate a probability
terminology_fixes_only.issue: Term 'Monte Carlo' is intimidating; concept is age-appropriate
terminology_fixes_only.recommendation: RENAME to 'Run many trials to estimate a probability' or 'Use repeated simulation to estimate probability'
terminology_fixes_only.revised_title: Run many trials to estimate a probability

terminology_fixes_only.title: Monte Carlo simulations with loops
terminology_fixes_only.recommendation: RENAME to 'Repeated trial simulations with loops'

terminology_fixes_only.title: Compare distributions of data
terminology_fixes_only.recommendation: SIMPLIFY to 'Compare averages and ranges' or 'Compare data using mean and range'
terminology_fixes_only.revised_title: Compare datasets using averages and ranges
terminology_fixes_only.revised_description: Students compare two datasets by calculating and comparing their averages (means) and ranges (min to max), identifying which dataset tends higher or has more spread.

terminology_fixes_only.title: Represent an algorithm in pseudocode or text code
terminology_fixes_only.recommendation: ADD SCAFFOLDING: Provide fill-in-the-blank templates. Call it 'Plan an algorithm using words and steps' or keep 'pseudocode' but with heavy support
terminology_fixes_only.implementation_notes: Provide templates, focus on translating Scratch blocks to text description

terminology_fixes_only.title: Write and test pseudocode for a non-trivial algorithm
terminology_fixes_only.recommendation: Same as above - provide templates and scaffolding

enrichment_track_advanced_but_appropriat.title: Understand why different algorithms are chosen for different problems
enrichment_track_advanced_but_appropriat.reason: Meta-cognitive understanding of algorithm selection is advanced but valuable

enrichment_track_advanced_but_appropriat.title: Analyze an algorithm for correctness on edge cases
enrichment_track_advanced_but_appropriat.reason: Edge case analysis is sophisticated but important for advanced students

enrichment_track_advanced_but_appropriat.title: Analyze and improve an algorithm's representation
enrichment_track_advanced_but_appropriat.reason: Meta-level analysis of representations is advanced

enrichment_track_advanced_but_appropriat.title: Explain how pattern recognition leads to better algorithm design
enrichment_track_advanced_but_appropriat.reason: Meta-cognitive skill connecting patterns to design

enrichment_track_advanced_but_appropriat.title: Refactor a complex algorithm for clarity or efficiency
enrichment_track_advanced_but_appropriat.reason: Refactoring requires sophisticated understanding of code quality

enrichment_track_advanced_but_appropriat.title: Use advanced data structures for algorithms
enrichment_track_advanced_but_appropriat.reason: Advanced data structures beyond basic lists

ai_ethics_requires_scaffolding.title: Analyze bias in AI models trained on biased data
ai_ethics_requires_scaffolding.note: KEEP with concrete examples, avoid technical ML details
ai_ethics_requires_scaffolding.implementation_notes: Use concrete examples of biased datasets (facial recognition trained mostly on lighter skin tones, hiring AI trained on historical data). Show impacts, don't require understanding model architecture.

ai_ethics_requires_scaffolding.title: Examine bias in AI-generated images and discuss causes
ai_ethics_requires_scaffolding.note: KEEP - highly relevant and can be made concrete
ai_ethics_requires_scaffolding.implementation_notes: Show examples of biased outputs, discuss training data

ai_ethics_requires_scaffolding.title: Evaluate and mitigate bias in AI detection systems
ai_ethics_requires_scaffolding.note: Advanced but important - keep with scaffolding
ai_ethics_requires_scaffolding.implementation_notes: Use concrete examples, focus on testing with diverse inputs

ai_ethics_requires_scaffolding.title: Evaluate algorithmic bias in AI services
ai_ethics_requires_scaffolding.implementation_notes: Focus on recognizing bias in real services (search results, recommendations), not formal evaluation methods

standard_track_well_designed.title: Design a simulation for a real-world question
Design and populate a table for a real-world inventory or database
Identify and correct data quality issues
Formulate a clear, testable data question
Conduct a full multi-step experiment with hypothesis
Design modular, reusable custom blocks for a project
Execute a complete data investigation (question to analysis)

ui_recommendations.standard_display: Always visible in main skill tree
ui_recommendations.enrichment_display: Marked with star icon or 'Challenge' badge, optional branches
ui_recommendations.competition_display: Separate 'Competition Prep' section or clearly marked as advanced

teacher_guidance.standard: All students should master these skills
teacher_guidance.enrichment: For advanced students or those seeking deeper understanding; excellent for differentiation
teacher_guidance.competition: For students preparing for coding competitions or interested in advanced CS concepts
